text: Also, because neighboring string constants are automatically concatenated, you can code it like this too:

code:
s = ("this is my really, really, really, really, really, really, "  
     "really long string that I'd like to shorten.")

text: Note no plus sign, and I added the extra comma and space that follows the formatting of your example.
Personally I don't like the backslashes, and I recall reading somewhere that its use is actually deprecated in favor of this form which is more explicit.
Remember "Explicit is better than implicit.
I consider the backslash to be less clear and less useful because this is actually escaping the newline character.
It's not possible to put a line end comment after it if one should be necessary.
It is possible to do this with concatenated string constants:

code:
s = ("this is my really, really, really, really, really, really, " # comments ok
     "really long string that I'd like to shorten.")

text: Another good search phrase would be "python line continuation".
Implicit concatenation might be the cleanest solution:

code:
s = "this is my really, really, really, really, really, really," \
    " really long string that I'd like to shorten."

text: You lost a space, and you probably need a line continuation character, ie.

code:
s = "this is my really, really, really, really, really, really" +  \
    " really long string that I'd like to shorten."

text: or even:

code:
s = "this is my really, really, really, really, really, really"  \
    " really long string that I'd like to shorten."

text: Parens would also work instead of the line continuation, but you risk someone thinking you intended to have a tuple and had just forgotten a comma.
Take for instance:

code:
s = ("this is my really, really, really, really, really, really"
    " really long string that I'd like to shorten.")

text: versus:

code:
s = ("this is my really, really, really, really, really, really",
    " really long string that I'd like to shorten.")

text: With Python's dynamic typing, the code may run either way, but produce incorrect results with the one you didn't intend.
Backslash:

code:
s = "this is my really, really, really, really, really, really" +  \
    "really long string that I'd like to shorten."

text: or wrap in parens:

code:
s = ("this is my really, really, really, really, really, really" + 
    "really long string that I'd like to shorten.")

text: I think the most important word in your question was "suggests".
Coding standards are funny things.
Often the guidance they provide has a really good basis when it was written (e.g.
most terminals being unable to show > 80 characters on a line), but over time they become functionally obsolete, but still rigidly adhered to.
I guess what you need to do here is weigh up the relative merits of "breaking" that particular suggestion against the readability and mainatinability of your code.
